questions.text: What is the most common type of leukemia in adults?
questions.solution:
Chronic lymphoid leukemia (CLL) is the most common type of leukemia in adults.

The common types of leukemia in various age groups is as follows:

  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most common acute leukemia in adults
  • Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) - most common cancer in childhood. The most common subtype of ALL is B-cell ALL
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) - most common lymphoid malignancy in adults

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for acute myeloid leukemia?
questions.solution:
Evan's syndrome does not predispose to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The following conditions predispose to AML:

Genetic conditions:

  • Down's syndrome:
    • Young children <4 years
    • Typically of the acute megakaryocytic subtype and associated with GATA1 mutations
    • Excellent clinical outcomes 
  • Defective DNA repair in conditions like ataxia telangiectasia, Fanconi anemia, and Bloom syndrome 

Environmental factors:

  • Drugs: 
    • Alkylating agents - cyclophosphamide, melphalan, dacarbazine, platinum compounds, after 4-6 years of exposure
    • Topoisomerase II inhibitors - etoposide, after 1-3 years of exposure.
  • Radiation - high dose radiation, therapeutic radiation in patients exposed to alkylating agents
  • Chemicals - benzene, petroleum products, pesticide

Hematological disorders with increased risk of AML:

  • Myeloproliferative disorders
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Multiple myeloma

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was referred with recurrent bacterial infections. Parents report that their first child also had similar features and died at the age of 18 months from myeloid leukemia. Investigations revealed markedly reduced absolute neutrophil count. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of congenital neutropenia is suggestive of Kostmann syndrome. It is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Kostmann syndrome occurs due to mutations in the G-CSF receptor and neutrophil elastase. This causes bone marrow failure specifically in the myeloid lineage. It presents in young children as recurrent bacterial infections (such as otitis media, cellulitis) and oral ulcers. 

Option A: Bloom syndrome occurs due to defects in DNA repair. It is not associated with neutropenia but has a higher risk of AML. 

Option C: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome refers to congenital erythroid aplasia. It is also associated with a higher risk of AML. 

Option D: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is due to defective phagolysosome formation. It is not associated with neutropenia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is being evaluated for suspected acute myeloid leukemia. He reports a fast-growing swelling in his mouth for the past 1 week. On examination, there is a greenish gingival mass with a necrotic surface. This presentation is likely associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a chloroma. It is commonly associated with the M2 subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, also called AML with maturation.

Chloroma is also called myeloid sarcoma, extramedullary myeloid tumor, or granulocytic sarcoma. It is an extramedullary tumor mass consisting of myeloid blasts, with or without maturation. It is called chloroma due to the peculiar green color, caused by myeloperoxidase. The sites affected include orbit (most common), skull, oral cavity, paranasal sinuses, sternum, ribs, vertebrae, and pelvis.

Related Pearl: FAB classification

FAB classification High-Yield points
M0-minimal differentiation -
M1-without maturation -
M2 - with maturation

M4 - myelomonocytic
  • inv 16
  • t(16,16)

  • Gingival hyperplasia

M5a - monoblastic

M5b - monocytic
  • Organ infiltration
  • Gingival hyperplasia
  • Increased WBC count, fever
  • Sweet syndrome
M6 - erythroid
  • Therapy related
  • Erythemic myelosis, Di Guglielmo disease
  • Poor prognosis
M7 - megakaryocytic
  • CD 41/61
  • Bad prognosis
  • Down syndrome (good prognosis)
  • Bone marrow fibrosis (increased PDGF)

questions.text: Patients suffering from which type of AML are more prone to develop disseminated intravascular coagulation?
questions.solution:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is commonly seen in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

questions.text: Oral cavity examination of a 56-year-old man with suspected leukemia revealed the following. What subtype of AML is he likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given image shows swollen and spongy gums, indicating gum infiltration. This is a characteristic feature of acute monocytic leukemia (AML-M5).

Infiltration of the gingivae, skin, soft tissues or meninges with leukemic blasts is characteristic of the monocytic subtypes and those with 11q23 chromosomal abnormalities.

Less commonly, infiltration is also seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML-M4).

questions.text: Which of the following would be seen on flow cytometry of a patient with acute megakaryoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution:
On flow cytometry, the immunophenotype of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia is CD41 and/or CD61 positive (platelet-specific antigens).

Flow cytometry is useful in establishing the different subtypes of AML:

Phenotype CD markers
Myeloblastic CD11b,13,33,117
Promyelocytic(M3) CD13,33
Myelomonocytic(M4) CD11b,13,14,33
Monocytic(M5) CD11b,11c,13,14,33 
Erythroid(M6) Glycophorin,spectrin
Megakaryoblastic(M7) CD41,61
Basophilic CD11,13,33,123
Mast cell CD13,33,117

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the WHO classification of acute myeloid leukemia?

choices.text: The clinical features are not considered to define the subtype
The cutoff value of blast cells for diagnosis is 20%
It is only based on morphological features of myeloid precursors
Chromosomal translocations along with > 20% blasts are needed for diagnosis

questions.solution:
The cutoff value of blast cells for the diagnosis of AML is 20% according to the WHO classification. This classification is based on the clinical features, cytogenetic and molecular abnormalities in addition to morphology. This is in contrast to the previously used French-American-British (FAB) classification which was based on only morphology of myeloid precursors.

The major changes in the WHO classification in contrast to FAB classification are:

  • Blast cutoff for diagnosis of AML is 20% (30% in FAB classification) 
  • Specific chromosomal rearrangements such as t (8;21), inv(16), t(16;16) and t (15;17) can define AML even with < 20% blasts 
  • Immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) is used to differentiate AML from ALL and to identify some subtypes of AML 
  • Myeloid dysplasia with blasts between 20-30% can benefit from therapy for myelodysplastic syndrome (decitabine, 5-azacytidine, cedazuridine)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is referred for evaluation of severe anemia, persistent fever, and recurrent epistaxis. Lab investigations are given below. What is the diagnosis?

Hb = 6 g/dL

Total WBC count - 40,000/ mm3

Platelet count - 12,000/cu.mm

Bone marrow - 10% blasts, positive for t(8;21) translocation
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML).

According to the WHO criteria, the diagnosis of AML requires any one of the following:

  • Blast cell count ≥20% either in the peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • Presence of any one of the following cytogenetic abnormalities:
    • t(15;17) 
    • t(8;21) 
    • Inversion 16 or t(16;16)
    • t(9;22)
    • NPM1 mutation (Nucleophosmin mutation)
    • CEBPA mutation
    • FLT3-ITD

questions.text: Patients with all of the following are classified as AML with recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities except:
questions.solution:
The chromosomal translocation t(9,22) is called the Philadelphia chromosome. It is seen in patients with CML.

AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities includes the following chromosomal aberrations:

  • t(15;17) 
  • t(8;21) 
  • Inversion 16 or t(16;16)

Two gene mutations have been added to the criteria of AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities in addition to chromosomal aberrations. Both gene mutations are associated with a good prognosis.

  • NPM1 mutation: Nucleophosmin mutation
  • CEBPA mutation

Related Pearl: Important Translocations in AML

Translocation t(8,21)

(most common) 

 t(15,17) t(16,16) or inv(16)
Fusion gene

RUNX1-RUNX1T1

 PML-RARα CBF-β (Core binding factor)
FAB classification

Blasts with maturation/M2

 Acute promyelocytic leukemia/M3 Myelomonocytic/M4
Clinical association Myeloid sarcoma/ chloroma DIC Eosinophilia
Prognosis Good Very good Good

questions.text: Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is seen in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia?
questions.solution:
t(15,17) is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

Related Pearl: Important Translocations in AML

Translocation t(8,21)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with fatigue and fever for the past 2 months. Investigations revealed pancytopenia and the following peripheral smear findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing blast cells with peroxidase granules are suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Peroxidase granules are dark blue-stained granules seen in the cytoplasm on peroxidase staining. 

Myeloperoxidase cytochemical activity is negative in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and blast crisis.

Related Pearl: Cytochemistry of Acute Leukemias

Stain AML ALL
Myeloperoxidase + -
Sudan black + -
Non-specific esterase

Strongly +ve: M4, M5

Weakly +ve: M3, M7

 _
Periodic acid Schiff +ve in AML M6 +
Acid phosphatase - + (T-cell)

questions.text: Which of the following patients with AML has a better prognosis than the others?

choices.text: A 48-year-old man newly diagnosed with AML with a family history of lymphoma
A 60-year-old woman who developed AML following chemotherapy for ovarian cancer
A 71-year-old man with a longstanding history of myelodysplastic syndrome
A 67-year-old woman evaluated with a 4-month history of pancytopenia prior to diagnosis

questions.solution:
Young age of onset is associated with a good prognosis in patients with AML. Family history does not affect the prognosis.

Poor prognosis is seen in the following cases:

  • Advancing age (usually defined as > 60 years) 
  • Previous hematologic disorders - myeloproliferative neoplasms and myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Longstanding cytopenias >3 months before diagnosis 
  • Therapy-related AML (chemotherapy for other cancers)
  • Chromosomal aberrations with poor outcomes

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the peripheral smear of a patient with suspected leukemia. All of the following features are suggestive of a myeloblast except:
questions.solution:
Pelger-Huet anomaly is not a feature of myeloblasts. Auer rods and Phi bodies are considered pathognomonic of AML.

Myeloblasts have the following characteristics as shown in the following image:

  • Large, uniform population of cells
  • Prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow in the image)
  • Primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods - needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by fusion of lysosomes (black arrow)
  • Phi-bodies - fusiform or spindle-shaped rods similar to Auer rods that require special stains for hydroperoxidases
  • Pseudo-Chediak-Higashi syndrome - Giant lysosomes forming intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to neutrophils with bilobed nuclei that occur as a benign, inherited condition. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to an acquired defect seen in CML, myelodysplastic syndrome. 

Note: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with abnormal lysosomal trafficking (LYST gene). Presents with oculocutaneous albinism and immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with a sudden-onset fever and the following painful rash over her face and upper limbs. CBC reveals neutrophilia. This presentation is associated with all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation with painful edematous plaques is suggestive of febrile neutrophilic dermatosis or Sweet syndrome. It is not associated with aplastic anemia. It is associated with the following conditions:

  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most common
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Solid malignancies of the genitourinary tract
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Drugs - all-trans-retinoic acid, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF)
  • Idiopathic Sweet syndrome - common in women following respiratory tract infection

This condition presents with the following triad:

  • Fever
  • Neutrophilia
  • Dense dermal infiltrate of neutrophils: 
    • Pinkish-red to reddish-brown edematous painful plaques
    • Occur over the head, neck, extremities

questions.text: What is the most commonly used complete remission induction regimen in patients with AML?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used complete remission induction regimen in patients with AML is cytarabine and an anthracycline (e.g., daunorubicin, idarubicin).

The treatment of AML is as follows:

  • Induction chemotherapy with a 7+3 regimen: 
    • Cytarabine - continuous intravenous infusion for 7 days
    • IV daunorubicin on days 1,2,3
    • Side effects include neutropenia, sepsis
  • Post-remission therapy: 
    • High dose cytarabine
    • Allogenic hematopoeitic stem cell transplant

Novel agents include gemtuzumab ozogamicin, a CD33 monoclonal antibody.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man came with generalized bone pain, and easy bruisability for the past 6 months. His WBC count was 60,000 cu. mm and bone marrow aspiration revealed the following. Immunohistochemistry was positive for MPO and cytogenetic studies showed presence of t(15:17). What is the preferred treatment regimen?

choices.text: Arsenic trioxide and all transretinoic acid

questions.solution:
The presence of blast cells with numerous Auer rods, MPO (myeloperoxidase) positive cells, and t(15:17) is diagnostic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The preferred treatment regimen is arsenic trioxide and all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA).

APL is characterized by t(15; 17) translocation resulting in the PML-RAR-alpha fusion gene (promyelocyte-retinoic acid receptor alpha). It is a highly curable subtype of leukemia. The treatment is as follows:

  • Induction therapy:
    • ATRA + anthracycline (daunorubicin or idarubicin) or cytarabine (OR)
    • ATRA + arsenic trioxide 
  • Consolidation therapy:
    • Post remission anthracycline-based chemotherapy

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient of APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) developing fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates while on medical treatment. This is suggestive of APL differentiation syndrome, an adverse effect of all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA). The management involves glucocorticoids like dexamethasone. 

Along with glucocorticoids, the other management of APL differentiation syndrome includes chemotherapy for cytoreduction and supportive measures. In severe cases, temporary discontinuation of ATRA is necessary.

ATRA is an oral drug that induces the differentiation of leukemic cells bearing the t(15;17) chromosomal translocation. While ATRA reduces the incidence of DIC associated with cytarabine and daunorubicin used earlier in APL, it can cause APL differentiation syndrome due to the adhesion of differentiated neoplastic cells to the pulmonary vasculature endothelium.

In low-risk APL patients with a low leukocyte count at presentation, a combination of ATRA and arsenic trioxide (ATO) has been found to be superior and is the current standard of care.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?

choices.text: His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+
An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O–

questions.solution:
In the case of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), allogeneic stem cell transplants are the treatment of choice. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is blood type O positive would be the best choice.

Other options:

Option A: An identical twin brother would not be the donor of choice. The therapeutic benefit of stem cell transplant in hematological malignancies is due to the graft-versus-leukemia (GvL). Donor T lymphocytes attack malignant hematopoietic stem cells of the recipient that remain after high-dose chemotherapy. Despite having a low rate of graft versus host disease (GvHD), stem cells from an identical twin do not have a desirable degree of GvL effect, leading to higher rates of recurrence post-transplant. 

Option B: Autologous (umbilical cord transplant) is not recommended as higher rates of relapse have been reported.

Option D: An HLA identical sibling is preferred over an unrelated HLA identical donor because there is a greater chance of matching for minor histocompatibility complex (mHC). This reduces the risk of GvHD. ABO compatibility is also important to consider, but a minor ABO mismatch (Rh mismatch) doesn't have any impact on hemolysis, graft-versus-host disease, or survival.

questions.text: Individuals in which age group have the highest incidence of T-cell acute lymphoblastic lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The highest incidence of T-ALL (T-cell acute lymphoblastic lymphoma) is at 10-19 years (adolescence) when the thymus reaches the maximum size.

On the other hand, B-ALL which is more common has a peak incidence at 3 years (1-10 years). At this age, the number of normal bone marrow pre-B cells (the cell of origin) is at its greatest.

questions.text: Children with Down's syndrome are at an increased risk of developing all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Down's syndrome is not associated with myelodysplastic disorder. These patients are at increased risk of developing the following conditions:

  • Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) - most commonly B-cell ALL
  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most commonly M7/megakaryoblastic subtype
  • Transient myeloproliferative disorder:
    • Associated with GATA1 mutations.
    • Seen in 10% of neonates, resolves in first 3 months of life
    • Require close follow-up as 20-30% may develop AML by 3 years of life

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought with fever, weight loss,  and easy bruisability. Initial examination revealed severe pallor and significant lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear revealed the following cells, which were also seen on bone marrow studies. Further investigations revealed CD10+ cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing blast cells in a young child are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The presence of CD10 is diagnostic of pre-B-cell ALL.

CD10 is also called the common ALL antigen (CALLA). It is the specific immunohistochemical marker for pre-B cell ALL. This is the most common type of ALL and is associated with a good prognosis. However, CD10 is negative in infantile leukemia, which is associated with translocation (4;11).

The immunohistochemistry of ALL is as follows:

Type CD marker
pro-B cell CD34, CD19, CD79a
pre- B cell CD19, CD79a, CD10, Tdt, Cytoplasmic Ig
Mature B cell CD19, CD79a,CD20, CD21,CD22, Surface IgM and D
T cell CD 2,3,4,5,6,7

Other abnormalities in ALL include:

  Good prognosis Bad prognosis
Cytogenic t(12,21)

t(9,22), t(4,11)

Burkitt lymphoma-associated ALL / ALL-L3 - t(2,8) , t(8,14), t(8,22)
Molecular

Hyperdiploidy

HOX

NOTCH 1 mutations

Hypodiploidy

questions.text:
Which of the following indicate a good prognosis in children diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
  1. Age < 1 year
  2. Mild hepatosplenomegaly
  3. Hyperdiploidy
  4. Female sex
  5. WBC count < 50,000 per mm3
questions.solution:
In children with ALL, a good prognosis is indicated by low WBC count, female sex, and hyperdiploidy.

Other abnormalities in ALL include:

  Good prognosis Bad prognosis
Cytogenic t(12,21)

t(9,22), t(4,11)

Burkitt lymphoma-associated ALL / ALL-L3 - t(2,8) , t(8,14), t(8,22)
Molecular

Hyperdiploidy

NOTCH 1

HOX

 Hypodiploidy

Related Pearl: Prognostic factors in ALL

Prognostic factors in ALL

 Prognostic factors Good Bad
Age 2-9 years <1 year or >10 years
Sex Female Male
Race White Black
CNS leukemia Absent Overt
Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy Absent Massive
Mediastinal mass Absent Present
Testicular involvement Absent Present
WBC count <50,000/mm3 >50,000/mm3
FAB Type L1 L2,L3
Cytogenetics Hyperdiploidy Hypodiploidy
Immunophenotype B-cell, early pre-B T cell
Translocation T(12,21),Notch 1,HOX 11 t(9,22),t(4,11)

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with Down's syndrome was brought with recurrent infections and bruising over his legs. Further workup was diagnostic of acute lymphoblastic leukemia and he was started on chemotherapy. Which of the following must be added on to prevent metastases to the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Intrathecal methotrexate is used for CNS prophylaxis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is essential in this condition as nearly 1/3 of patients develop CNS involvement at relapse without prophylactic therapy.

The treatment of ALL is as follows:

Induction (4 weeks):

  • L-Asparaginase:
    • Single-dose
    • Side effects - pancreatitis, thrombosis
  • Vincristine:
    • Weekly
    • Side effects - neuropathy, SIADH
  • Prednisolone

Consolidation: Intrathecal methotrexate

Maintenance (24-36 months):

  • 6-Mercaptopurine
  • Methotrexate
